title: Friday, 3rd November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hiya

PM11:03am

The mania over clown finance has reached Christine Lagarde

PM11:03am

So i guess she can be our pic for today

11:03 am
PM11:03am

PM11:04am

Virtual currencies are in a different category, because they provide their own unit of account and payment systems. These systems allow for peer-to-peer transactions without central clearinghouses, without central banks.

For now, virtual currencies such as Bitcoin pose little or no challenge to the existing order of fiat currencies and central banks. Why? Because they are too volatile, too risky, too energy intensive, and because the underlying technologies are not yet scalable. Many are too opaque for regulators; and some have been hacked.

PM11:04am

https://www.imf.or...-a-brave-new-world

11:04 am
PM11:05am

Mme Lagarde wil not be getting a job at JP Morgan any time soon

PM11:05am

But then if she's playing bitcoin already, she won't need to work!

PM11:05am

It's up another 5% overnight

11:05 am
PM11:06am

$7427 on my screen

PM11:06am

Nuts

UK Tech Awards 2017 journalist of the year. Which is pretty great really, given it's the sector he's singlehandedly destroying like the traitor to British entrepreneurism that he is.

PM11:08am

hehehe

Wide shot:

11:08 am

https://twitter.com/PwCLondon/status/926201542516051968

undefined
11:10 am
PM11:10am

So the Footsie is up, a bit

PM11:10am

Plenty of trading statement

BE11:10am

(@Wayne: come the Revolution, watch which wall you're standing near. That's all I'm saying.)

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Though the more interesting statements are from things not trading.

PM11:10am

There's a float and two not gonna float nows.

BE11:11am

Yep, we have failed IPO Friday's.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

PM11:11am

What did you have in mind Bryce?

BE11:11am

I'm mostly fascinated by the reasons for pulling here. Arqiva went for "market uncertainty”.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Bakkavor has gone for a slightly more complicated excuse.

BE11:11am

Bakkavor said it had received sufficient demand from financial institutions for its shares. However, a person close to the company said its directors and bankers had nevertheless decided that conditions had become unsuitable for a stock market debut.

BE11:12am

https://www.ft.com...-9836-b25f8adaa111

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Yep, sure, sounds legit. They totally could sell, but they changed their mind for reasons. And their girlfriend lives in Canada. Super. Fine.

BE11:12am

Because, I mean, it'd be properly embarrasing if HSBC, Morgan Stanley, Barclays and Citi (all bookrunners) failed to get away the £300m or so Bakkavor was raising.

BE11:13am

(Peel Hunt and Rabobank (managers) and Rothschild (advisor) make up that team, by the way. Though when you pull and IPO it seems that the tombstone doesn't go on the RNS.)

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And to be fair, it has certainly been turmoil out there .... just look at the FTSE100.

BE11:13am

PM11:13am

Notice that neither of those not gonna float statements has a banks' name on them,

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Let's fill in the gaps then. Arqiva was HSBC, Goldman and Cazenove as bookrunners.Rothschild advising. Tried to sell about £1.5bn, failed.

BE11:14am

However, the good news you allude to earlier is that there's enough appetite for Oleg Deripaska’s EN+ thing.

BE11:14am

Whose international depository listing was priced at the bottom of the range: https://www.ft.com...-b8a3-38a6e068f464

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Which I guess is a reasonable indicator of the direction of travel for the London market.

PM11:17am

Meanwhile, this Boku thing is floating

PM11:17am

https://www.invest...1711030700044606V/

11:17 am
PM11:17am

Mobile payments

PM11:17am

But why is it floating here -- on AIM??

PM11:18am

It's based in San Francisco

11:18 am
PM11:19am

It's last funding round was led by UK investors

PM11:19am

But this is very much a Silicon Valley thing

PM11:19am

See how Peel Hunt get on selling that

11:19 am
undefined
PM11:21am

So Smith & Nephew statement

Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,400, up 17.3 (+1.25%), High: 1,402, Low: 1,335, Volume: 1.63m
11:21 am
PM11:21am

All the news coverage suggested real problems.

PM11:22am

But that's not reflected in the market reaction

PM11:22am

https://www.invest...1711030700034599V/

11:22 am
BE11:22am

The thing with Smith & Nephew is that we have exceptionally good visibility on what it's about to say .....

BE11:22am

..... because it's the last of the ortho sector to report every quarter.

PM11:23am

Oh i see

11:23 am
BE11:23am

So, the guidance for bottom of the range was already anticipated post the Zimmer warning a few days ago, among others.

BE11:24am

We flagged the prospect here, in fact. https://www.ft.com...-9836-b25f8adaa111

BE11:24am

And the US hurricanes weren't really a surprise either. There was a fair bit of news coverage.

11:24 am
PM11:24am

hehe

BE11:25am

Because Florida is the international epicentre of hip replacements, the numbers come back when it gets a bit windy because the routine surgery is deferred. Again, known.

BE11:26am

S&N also flags up Europe remaining a bit weak, which we knew .....

11:26 am
PM11:26am

Do they tell us anything at all that we didn't know?

BE11:26am

Well .... S&N makes some noises about costs, which might be Elliott's doing

BE11:28am

Arash had a good story last Friday, I think, that set out what Elliott wants from S&N, and the apparent answer is "not much".

11:29 am
BE11:29am

.... which has moved some people towards a suggestion that Elliott is now spreading itself pretty wide and getting into a whole load of positions, without a clear idea of what its endgame is.

BE11:30am

https://www.ft.com...-a398-73d59db9e399

PM11:30am

That's a very good point -- Elliott must be stretched

11:30 am
BE11:31am

Victim of its own success, arguably. Too much money to invest, not enough special sits to invest in.

BE11:31am

Anyway, here's Citi.

BE11:31am

It looks like S&N had a fine Q3 with results pretty much in line with
consensus. Group sales were $1,152mn (vs consensus $1,160mn) on organic growth of 2.6%, despite the fact the quarter was impacted by the hurricane in the US which provided around a $300mn headwind to sales (-40bps to organic growth in Q3).

11:31 am
BE11:31am

The knee division continued its solid performance with
organic growth of +6%, while hips remained challenged at 1%. Advanced Wound Devices and Sports Medicine continued to be the highest growth division, both at +8% organic growth, whereas Trauma and the Arthroscopic Enabled Technologies division lagged at -2% and -3% organic growth respectively. Overall, it looks like a decent performance for S&N in Q3 for growth as far as we can see.

BE11:32am

Full year outlook at lower end of guidance range — Smith & Nephew continues to expect underlying sales growth in FY17E of +3-4%, with an EBITA margin expansion of +20-70bps, but commented that it expects to be at the lower end of guidance in both sales growth and margin expansion.
 Implications — We see limited changes to consensus on the back of these results, given consensus is already at the lower end of the range for full year guidance. The key focus for investors still remains around the reported Elliot stake in S&N and what this means for the business long term

BE11:32am

And Numis, briefly.

11:01 am
PM11:01am

Welcome to Markets Live

undefined
BE11:34am

Otherwise in update, we have Lonmin ......

11:34 am
Lonmin PLC (LMI:LSE): Last: 82.25, down 22 (-21.10%), High: 104.50, Low: 78.50, Volume: 12.74m
BE11:34am

So, good news and bad news.

PM11:34am

https://www.invest...1711030700034681V/

11:34 am
BE11:34am

The good news is that production's beginning to show some momentum.

PM11:35am

Imagine having an "Overview" statement that begins with...

PM11:35am

Fatality free quarter

11:35 am
PM11:35am

But sorry, go on Bryce

BE11:36am

Yeah, mining as a whole has a few issues about risk and reward, and I don't mean in an investment sense.

BE11:36am

Aside from the fatalities (zero) we have concentrate production of 187koz in the quarter, up from 171koz last time.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

So, annual sales beat the guidance of 650-680koz

BE11:37am

All fine! All coming to plan! Except it can't actually publish FY results.

BE11:38am

Talks with lenders won't allow it.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

RBC summarises where we are .....

BE11:38am

The company has already announced that its lenders have granted it a pre-emptive waiver around the tangible net worth covenant for 30 September 2017; however, Lonmin notes that continuing discussions around the Operating Review, along with discussions with existing and prospective lenders around its business plan, including views on development capex and Rowland MK2, could have bearing on impairments (and therefore potentially result in covenant concerns, we think) and/or whether the FY17E financial statements are prepared on a going concern basis. The company also points to the potential for new debt capital. As a result of the ongoing Operational Review and the uncertainty around the future of the business that this creates, the company and its auditors require additional time to complete the FY17E results, which have as a result been delayed from 13 November

BE11:39am

We continue to have concerns over the longer-term viability of Lonmin given the high cost, labour intensive operations, and the company’s limited capital investment in its operations (under the current strategy it invests the minimum amount possible to ensure that it operates safely and with sufficient flexibility, although we note that immediately available ore reserves are falling, currently at 19 months vs. 22 months at end-16, but still provide sufficient flexibility). While the initial read on the operational results is positive, we see the developments around the delayed operational review and accounts (plus a flagged potential going concern issue) as an overarching negative.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

The problem here, of course, is that Lonmin didn't raise enough money with its rescue rights issue. As we said at the time, and many many many many times since.

BE11:40am

Nedbank incoming.

BE11:41am

These are good numbers from Lonmin, but rising costs essentially
mean that Lonmin is still running just to stand still. We strongly
believe that Lonmin will have to be recapitalised in order to grow
production back to sustainable profit levels.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

The review Lonmin's currently stalled at includes Tangible Net Worth, Nedbank notes, "could also impact the debt covenants and could thus have significant implications for the company on an ongoing basis."

BE11:42am

We also note the PIC announced that it has increased its holding in Sibanye to just under 11%. Could this point to the long-expected combination of Lonmin and Sibanye? A merger with Sibanye could resolve some of the pressure (such a deal will yield better margins
for Sibanye not having to pay the offtake to Amplats)

BE11:42am

Although we still see a deal between the parties being possible,
we do not believe it is imminent, given the offtake agreement
between Sibanye and Amplats that still has some three years to
run plus then a two year notice (and due to Sibanye’s high debt
levels which the company intends to reduce). Therefore, we
expect Lonmin’s output to continue to decline in the absence of a
capital injection. This lower output should be good for the metal
price basket. We maintain our Sell recommendation.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

The longer term share price chart for Lonmin is comical

PM11:43am

It's down from £40,000 to 82p

PM11:43am

In the space of a decade

11:44 am
BE11:44am

(@GBKrona: I think because, having had three rights issues in eight years, the last one at a 94% discount less than two years ago, folk might be a bit cautious buying underwater yet again.)

undefined
PM11:46am

Tate & Lyle. One of your fav subjects Bryce

11:46 am
PM11:46am

strong today

PM11:46am

Were the interims yesterday?

BE11:47am

They've stopped sending me their ingredient launch press releases, which is very disappointing.

11:46 am
PM11:47am

Oh no!

BE11:48am

I used to really enjoy reading about neutrally balanced synthetic texture enhancers

PM11:48am

Liberum rather enthusiastic today

11:48 am
PM11:48am

850p price target

BE11:48am

Go on ....

PM11:49am

Actually, just a short note

11:49 am
PM11:49am

1H results demonstrate that Tate is making solid progress toward the group’s 2020 targets. We expect rising margins, returns and cash flow, especially in Speciality Food Ingredients. In FY’18 we forecast 15% growth in pre-tax profits to £311m driven by rising core SFI margins, recovery at Food Systems and solid Bulk profits. Despite a rising tax rate, we expect a 5% FY17-22E EPS CAGR with upside risk from faster volume growth or more positive mix..

Progress toward 2020 goals

Tate’s strategy to focus on speciality ingredients is the right one. There is steady progress toward the strategic 2020 ambitions although we await acceleration in SFI volume growth.

+2% DPS shows confidence

Solid cash flow supports investment and a progressive dividend. Tate lifted the interim dividend by 2% reflecting confidence in future growth coupled with rebuilding DPS cover.

Upside risks to margins

We see upside risk to margins and profits if Tate accelerates its strategic shift to SFI. We advocate selling sucralose and reinvesting in bolt-on M&A focused on SFI and EMs.

Valuation undemanding

Tate trades on cal’18E P/E of 13x, a 16% discount to global peer Ingredion. Looking out a few years valuation drops quickly as Tate continues to execute its LT strategy.

Steady SFI margin expansion drives sustainable group uplift

Tate & Lyle PLC (TATE:LSE): Last: 696.50, up 21 (+3.11%), High: 704.00, Low: 682.32, Volume: 1.56m
BE11:50am

There's also an Exane upgrade. Bloomberg saying Exane were the last sellers out there .....

11:50 am
BE11:51am

.... though the note isn't exactly enthusiastic.

BE11:51am

While in our view Tate is a commoditised business with low/no organic growth prospects, we believe that this is now largely reflected in its share price.

BE11:51am

That's it, basically.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Jefferies do a more thorough job of setting out the buy case.

BE11:52am

(Jefferies is shop, BTW.)

BE11:52am

Tate still has work to do to shift the cloud of ambivalence that hangs over it. Trademark caution on H2, incremental tax headwinds & a beat skewed to perceivedas-lower-quality Bulk have all contributed to the mood of ennui

11:52 am
BE11:53am

Martin Deboo, of course.

BE11:53am

Plenty of good news for us. A price is being paid for educating the market inadvertently that SFI = good & Bulk = bad, with the beat to our numbers concentrated in the latter. We remain of the view that aggregate return from the US corn processing assets is what matters, where H1 profits were ahead more than 20% at constant fx and pre-tax ROIC was c.18%. But even we have been impressed by the return of Speciality Starches to volume growth in North America, bucking the trend of tough markets.

BE11:54am

Time to lose some virginity on M&A. Cash dividend cover has been rebuilt and net debt:EBITDA is heading to less than 1x. More importantly, there is now an operating & go-tomarket model on which fresh baubles can be hung, profitably. Tate can't afford anything truly transformational but they can afford something materially accretive and capabilityenhancing. For too long Ingredion have led the supermarket sweep of SFI assets to an audience of US investors willing to capitalise EPS accretion less questioningly. But Tate should now be able to get more comfort around the synergies required to accommodate their ROIC greater than WACC sensibilities.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

The backstory here is that Tate sold off because of Trump being Trump about Nafta, and has subsequently rallied a bit.

undefined
PM11:55am

On the subject of floats and now not gonna floats

11:55 am
PM11:55am

We didn't mention Footasylum yesterday

PM11:55am

Lets see whether the ticker works

Footasylum PLC (FOOT:LSE): Last: 196.11, up 5.11 (+2.68%), High: 201.70, Low: 194.00, Volume: 149.50k

BE11:57am

It's done okay then. JD Sports effect, I guess. Investors believe differentiated retailers that .... that, well, don't look like Sports Direct's floorspace jumble sale ..... will keep running.

11:58 am
PM11:58am

(Jaws -- thanks. That doesnt look like a broken IPO market to me.)

BE11:59am

See the recent investor day thing from Nike where they talked about starving the poor quality third-party chains and supporting those giving a better shopping experience.

BE12:00pm

I ....... guess ........... Footasylum fits that? Maybe? It's upscale-ish, right?

12:00 pm
PM12:01pm

https://www.footas...m/mens-department/

PM12:01pm

Nike trainers look the same on every site to me

BE12:01pm

I don't think we're their target market, to be fair.

12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

Any retailer floating with a pitch of "sportswear for middle-aged financial journalists" is probably going to struggle a bit.

PM12:03pm

This is true

undefined
12:03 pm
PM12:03pm

Look at the time

PM12:04pm

Trump has been going nuts on the Crooked Hilary theme while we've been on air.

PM12:04pm

Five tweets on the matter today so far

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

What's he trying to distract attention from?

BE12:04pm

As someone smarter than me observed, he'll never forgive Hillary for losing the election and making him president.

PM12:04pm

I wont bother sharing

12:05 pm
PM12:05pm

Excellent gag

PM12:05pm

We should close up

PM12:06pm

Thanks for joining us on the right

12:05 pm
PM12:06pm

Cheers Bryce

PM12:06pm

Back on Monday

PM12:06pm

Have a good weekend

12:06 pm
PM12:06pm

Bye

BE11:33am

A positive tone on the call from management highlighting areas of focus include simplifying manufacturing, warehousing & distribution, G&A expenses (9% of sales, ahead of peers) & sales force effectiveness. No structural changes in commercial teams - to leverage those teams to drive effectiveness so is expected to be a 'lower risk' approach than previous programmes. Despite the recent sports medicine acquisition of Rotation Medical for $125m upfront & $85m over 5 years, S&N retains significant balance sheet flexibility at less than 1x net debt/EBITDA for further bolt-on activity to leverage its significant infrastructure. S&N trades at 11.3x 2018E EV/EBITDA, which we view as well-supported.
